steps.text: Identify potential fire risks in working machines.
Evaluate each machine's operating environment and conditions.
Issue clear instructions for safety.
Supervise compliance with safety instructions.
Assess fire risks by considering impact on company's other risks, level of risk taken, employee actions in an accident, adequacy of preventive maintenance, and daily work.
Begin fire timeline when a machine is put into service.
Perform scheduled maintenance according to manufacturer's instructions.
Use authentic replacement parts.
Inspect and clean engine compartment and surroundings daily in fire-hazard conditions.
Inspect and clean engine compartment and surroundings weekly in other environments.
Clean engine compartment at least once a week.
Use compressed air to remove dirt after cleaning.
Inspect for leaks after cleaning.
Visually inspect electrical systems at least once a year.
Service electrical systems daily on electric-powered and hybrid machines.
Use a multimeter to measure voltage drops.
Use a thermal imaging camera to detect anomalies.
Repair any leaks and electrical issues.
Check battery terminals for integrity.
Inspect cables for damage and cleanliness.
Examine electric panel for redundant wires.
Attach cables with fasteners in engine compartment.
Check alternator for firm attachment and cleanliness.
Examine exhaust pipe for leaks and thermal shields.
Inspect urea systems and diesel particulate filter for contamination.
Check urea system for leaks and prevent contamination during refueling.
Ensure regeneration occurs in a safe outdoor environment.
Delay regeneration if machine is in a fire-hazard environment.
Never leave machine unattended during regeneration.
Inspect swivelling joint hoses and electrical systems weekly.
Ensure all operating manuals are available in a language the operator understands.
Check auxiliary heater cleanliness and condition before winter.
Ensure heater compartment is clean and free of fuel leaks.
Inspect heater's exhaust pipe for contact with flammable materials.
Test heater under supervision before use.
Check signs and markings.
Inspect machine electrical systems (battery cables, harnesses, main power switch, alternator).
Examine engine mechanics (fuel/oil/hydraulic lines, exhaust system).
Inspect first-aid extinguishing equipment (hand-held extinguishers, system log).
Assess auxiliary heater (installation, fuel manifold, exhaust, electrical system).
Check mains power systems.
Evaluate general condition and cleanliness.
Check cables and fasteners for security, heat resistance, insulation, and lead-throughs.
Inspect fuses and batteries for the condition of non-fused cables and terminal covers.
Examine engine and heater compartments for cleanliness and leaks.
Verify availability, markings, and operator training of first-aid extinguishing equipment.

constraints.text: Consider the machine's operating environment and conditions when evaluating fire risks.
Operating environment affects potential impact of a fire.
Fire risk arises as soon as a machine is taken into service.
Shut down engine before inspecting for fuel leaks.
Protect hydraulic hoses from hot surfaces or high-temperature materials.
Check main power switch location and operation.
Repair any malfunction before resuming operation.
Replace cables showing signs of abrasion or heat damage.
Ensure fuses are the correct size.
Ensure regeneration occurs in a safe outdoor environment away from flammable materials.
Delay regeneration if machine is in a fire-hazard environment.
Perform inspections in the specified order.
